moves.1. c4: This is a good example of how a chess game can suddenly change course mid-game. In this game I make two critical mistakes, the second of which quickly lost me the match
moves.2... Qf6: and black brings out its queen?!?! a basic rule of chess is to never bring out the queen too early.
moves.3. g3: preparing to bring my bishop to the long diagonal (I know there's a proper name for this but I forgot how to spell it)
moves.3... Bc5: Black's plan is clear now; Scholar's Mate. Not a potent attack if the opponent can recognise the danger...
moves.4... Nh6: ? that's not usually a good place for a knight... If Black wanted to develop it then Ne7 would be far more preferable
moves.5. Nd5: attacking, putting my knight onto a good square and threatening a fork! (though maybe I should have moved my bishop first?)
moves.5... Qd6: this,Qd8 and Qc6 both work to stop the fork, but I prefer this because it keeps the queen active, whereas Qd8 wastes a lot of tempo for Black (and Qc6? threatens a discovered attack after Bf2, with the added danger of the knight playing Nf6 after that)
moves.6. Bg2 b6: ? bad move considering the position of Fou Leblanc... 6...c6 would be far better
moves.7. Ne3: setting the attack up (I love the position of my knights here, btw :) )
moves.7... a5: Black also had the option of 7...Bb7 8. Nh4 Bxg2 9.Nxg2
moves.9... Qg6: while Black goes for the attack, though I think it should have gone for more development
moves.10... f6: but Black just launches a fresh attack!
moves.11. Ne4: Nh3?? d6! (my knights are in a nice adjacent line again - something about this position looks really cool to me!)
moves.13. Nxc7+: King fork! (do I keep saying that in my games? I'm thinking of making it into my own personal catchphrase! :P)
moves.13... Kd8 14. Nxb5 Bxe4: ?? what was once a dangerous move is nullified by the obvious threat on the rook
moves.15... Qxe4 16. Nxa7 Qxc4: Black grabs the pawn, but ultimately White has gained a rook and pawn for a knight (cancelling out the similar pieces on both sides - and that is how I use Maths in chess!)
moves.17... Qa6: (!) ouch! Black reclaims his lost material points (if I had forseen this move, then 17. e3 Qa6 18. Qf3)
moves.18. g4: there's no way to save the knight, so there's no point trying.
moves.18... Qxa7 19. g5: an attack on the knight (I can aim to double the pawns on the h-file with 19...fxg5 20.Bxg5+, then...21.Bxh6 gxh6)
moves.19... Ng4: ? a move which looks powerful on the outside, with a lot of pressure on the f2 pawn, but he should have played Nf5, because...
moves.20. e3: (!) the pressure is immediately revoked, and a discovered attack that the knight has no escape from
moves.21. Qxg4 Rf8 22. gxf6: an exchange of pawns, benefiting White
moves.22... Rxf6 23. Qxg7: ?? White is about to lose that material advantage - again!
moves.24. Qxg6 hxg6: equality is now reached once more - it's anyone's game right now
moves.25... Qa6 26. Rfc1: with hopes of doubling my rooks; the threat on Black's bishop forces it to move (26...Qxd3 loses to 27. Bd5+, then 28. Rxc5
moves.26... Be7 27. Rc3: ?? this was with the idea of protecting the d-pawn, but...
moves.27... Bb4: Pin! or is it a skewer! I need someone to clarify me on that - I'm not too sure on the difference between the two
moves.28... Qxd3: (!) I was expecting a bishop trade, but this was a nasty surprise - White's gonna be losing material no matter what it does!
moves.29. Bxb4 Qxc2 30. Bxa5+ Kc8 31. b4: and now, after spending the game simply catching up with lost material, Black has pulled ahead
moves.31... Nc6 32. h5: a last desperate attack, hoping Black will play Nxa5, giving me a chance of promotion...
moves.32... gxh5: Denied! And now, with my bishop and pawn stuck in their positions and the queen in such a powerful position (Qb2) I resigned.
